pullrequest.title: Update hook to clean .pyc files and empty folders

content.raw:
This is unsatisfactory because tortoisehg hangs if the hook is not present, meaning if you update to a revision where the hook doesn’t exist, you can’t get back with tortoisehg \(hg on the command line is fine, it just prints errors and keeps going\).

I’ll come up with something less flaky like hat, and also make the installer set up the hook rather than at runtime.

pullrequest.title: Update hook to clean .pyc files and empty folders

content.raw:
Ok, I’m happy with this now. Installing the hook copies it into the .hg directory so that it is self-contained and will work no matter whether the user moves the repository on disk or updates it to any revision. A list of Python interpreters that have been used to install the hook is saved so that on Windows the hook knows where Python is and can run, but if it can’t because no Python interpreter exists, it just prints a warning and so doesn’t prevent you from using mercurial normally.

The hook is not installed automatically every time you import labscript\_utils. Instead I’ll make the installer add the hook as part of registering the labscript install with the Python environment.

Once merged, you can also add the hook yourself to any repo by going to the repo in question and running:

    python -m labscript_utils.clean_repo_hook install
